title: GLM-5: From Vibe Coding to Agentic Engineering
description: Z.ai released GLM-5, a massive 754B parameter model (1.51TB). Notably, Z.ai is promoting the term 'Agentic Engineering' for professional software engineers building with LLMs, a term also adopted by Andrej Karpathy and Addy Osmani.
author: Simon Willison

title: OpenAI API now supports Skills with shell tool
description: OpenAI's adoption of Skills continues - you can now use Skills directly in the OpenAI API with their shell tool. Skills can be uploaded as base64-encoded zip data inline with JSON requests, making it easier to package and distribute agent capabilities.
author: Simon Willison

title: cysqlite: New Cython SQLite driver with custom virtual tables
description: Charles Leifer released cysqlite, a ground-up Cython rewrite of pysqlite3. Simon used Claude Code to build a WebAssembly version that runs in Pyodide. Key feature: support for custom virtual tables not available in standard library sqlite3.
author: Simon Willison

title: Introducing Showboat and Rodney: Tools for Agent Demos
description: Simon Willison released two new tools to address the challenge of having coding agents both test what they've built and demonstrate software to overseers. Showboat helps agents create demo artifacts, and Rodney complements it for testing and demonstration workflows.
author: Simon Willison

title: Fireship: The unhinged world of tech in 2026
description: Fireship's take on the rapid technological changes and chaos in the tech landscape of 2026, covering AI developments and industry shifts.
author: Fireship

title: Amjad Masad on Wall Street Journal: AI coding boom and stock selloff
description: Replit CEO Amjad Masad discussed the AI coding boom, recent software stock selloff, and the rise of 'vibecoding' in interviews across WSJ, Yahoo Finance, and News.com.au.
author: Amjad Masad

title: LLMs + Security = Trouble
description: Explores security constraints and concerns during LLM code generation.
author: ArXiv Researchers

title: Still Manual? Automated Linter Configuration via DSL-Based LLM
description: Automating linter configuration using LLMs and DSL-based compilation of coding standards.
author: ArXiv Researchers

title: You are Not Ready: Agentic coding in 2026
description: Discussion on AI coding tools crossing a threshold due to long-running agents, memory outside context windows, and evolving capabilities that enable more sophisticated autonomous coding workflows.
author: YouTube Channel (Two Minute Papers style)

title: Structured Context Engineering for File-Native Agentic Systems
description: New paper by Damon McMillan exploring LLM context tasks with large SQL schemas (up to 10,000 tables). Found frontier models (Opus 4.5, GPT-5.2, Gemini 2.5 Pro) beat open source models, and filesystem-based context retrieval helped frontier models significantly. TOON format showed 'grep tax' - models spent more tokens due to unfamiliarity.
author: Simon Willison (reviewing Damon McMillan paper)

title: AI Doesn't Reduce Work—It Intensifies It (Harvard Business Review)
description: Aruna Ranganathan and Xingqi Maggie Ye from Berkeley Haas report findings from studying 200 employees: AI introduced new rhythm of managing multiple active threads at once, creating cognitive load and sense of always juggling. Simon observes this matches his experience - can get so much done but mental energy depletes quickly.
author: Simon Willison (discussing HBR research)

title: OpenAI's new slop machine is open for business
description: Critical analysis of OpenAI's latest releases and their impact on AI-generated content quality.
author: Fireship

title: Secure Code Generation via Online Reinforcement Learning
description: Addresses LLM tendency to generate insecure code through online reinforcement learning approaches.
author: ArXiv Researchers

title: Adversarial LLM Agents for Robust Unit Test Generation
description: Introduces 'Test vs Mutant' approach using adversarial LLM agents to improve unit test generation quality and robustness.
author: ArXiv Researchers

title: Thomas Ptacek: Vulnerability research is THE most LLM-amenable software engineering problem
description: Responding to news that Claude Opus 4.6 uncovered 500 zero-day flaws in open-source, Thomas Ptacek argues vulnerability research may be the most LLM-amenable domain: pattern-driven, huge corpus of public patterns, closed loops, forward progress from stimulus/response tooling.
author: Thomas Ptacek (quoted by Simon Willison)

title: Inference-time Acquisition of Unfamiliar Programming Languages
description: Study of LLM proficiency in coding tasks across unfamiliar programming languages.
author: ArXiv Researchers

title: Claude Opus 4.6 fast mode: 2.5x faster at 6x the price
description: Anthropic released 'fast mode' for Claude Opus 4.6, offering 2.5x faster responses at 6x the normal price. Regular Opus: $5/million input, $25/million output. Fast mode: $30/million input, $150/million output. 50% discount until Feb 16 makes it 3x price temporarily.
author: Simon Willison

title: Vouch: Mitchell Hashimoto's system to address AI-generated PRs in open source
description: Mitchell Hashimoto released Vouch to help address the deluge of worthless AI-generated PRs. Unvouched users can't contribute to projects, and very bad users can be explicitly 'denounced'. Integration into GitHub is as simple as adopting published GitHub actions.
author: Simon Willison

title: Coding agents have replaced every framework I used
description: Major discussion on how agentic AI coding tools are replacing traditional frameworks, with developers and businesses potentially facing significant industry disruptions.
author: Hacker News Community

title: Software factories and the agentic moment
description: Discussion on the business model shift toward agentic AI development and emerging approaches like 'Canadian girlfriend coding' as new business paradigms.
author: Hacker News Community

title: David Crawshaw: Eight more months of agents
description: David Crawshaw shares that he's having more fun programming than ever because AI agents enable writing many more programs. He acknowledges fear about the end-game for intelligence in society but notes these tools have brought exploration and joy to his work in the limited domain of writing computer programs.
author: David Crawshaw (quoted by Simon Willison)

title: How StrongDM's AI team build serious software without even looking at the code
description: Simon Willison describes a demo from a team implementing what Dan Shapiro called the 'Dark Factory' level of AI adoption, where no human even looks at the code the coding agents are producing. The team uses extensive testing and simulation to prove the system works.
author: Simon Willison

title: Dynamic Assessment of LLM Code Generation in Game Arenas
description: Introduces 'ProxyWar,' a novel framework for systematically assessing code generation quality by embedding LLM-generated agents in game environments for dynamic evaluation.
author: ArXiv Researchers

title: Tom Dale: Nearly every software engineer experiencing mental health crisis
description: Tom Dale reports widespread mental health crisis among software engineers. Not just job loss anxiety, but near-manic episodes from watching software shift from scarce to abundant, compulsive agent usage, dissociative awe at temporal compression of change.
author: Tom Dale (quoted by Simon Willison)

title: Running Pydantic's Monty Rust sandboxed Python subset in WebAssembly
description: Simon got Pydantic's Monty (custom Python-like language in Rust for running untrusted code) working in WebAssembly, providing a sandbox-in-a-sandbox approach. Uses Claude Code extensively for the build process.
author: Simon Willison

title: Heroku transitions to sustaining engineering model
description: Heroku announced transition to 'sustaining engineering model' focused on stability, security, reliability, and support rather than new features. They're focusing investments on helping organizations build and deploy enterprise-grade AI.
author: Simon Willison

title: Karel D'Oosterlinck: Automating research at OpenAI with Codex
description: Karel describes using Codex to do extensive due diligence when implementing experiments. Codex explores relevant Slack channels, reads related discussions, fetches experimental branches, cherry picks useful changes, and summarizes everything in notes with links back to sources.
author: Karel D'Oosterlinck (quoted by Simon Willison)

title: Vibe Coding phenomenon: CEOs participating in prototype building
description: Amjad Masad discusses how AI is enabling 'vibe coding' - allowing non-technical executives, including CEOs, to participate in prototype building and software development without traditional coding skills.
author: Amjad Masad

title: Amjad Masad on Impact Theory: The Rise of Coding Agents and Functional AGI
description: Masad appeared on Tom Bilyeu's Impact Theory podcast discussing the rise of coding agents, functional AGI, and how AI is transforming industries and empowering non-coders. Replit now valued at $3B with $144M ARR and 150,000+ paying customers.
author: Amjad Masad

title: Anthropic releases Opus 4.6, OpenAI releases GPT-5.3-Codex
description: Two major model releases within 15 minutes of each other. Simon notes both are really good but struggles to find tasks that previous models couldn't handle. Most convincing story about new capabilities is Nicholas Carlini from Anthropic talking about Opus 4.6 and building a C compiler with a team of parallel Claudes.
author: Simon Willison

title: CIA World Factbook sunset: Cultural vandalism with 302 redirects
description: The CIA World Factbook, one of CIA's oldest publications since 1971, has sunset. In a bizarre act of cultural vandalism, they've not just removed the entire site but also set every page to 302 redirect to their closure announcement. Simon saved the 2020 version to GitHub.
author: Simon Willison

title: Mitchell Hashimoto's AI Adoption Journey: Reproduce work, end-of-day agents
description: Mitchell shares unconventional tips for getting coding agents to improve workflow: 1) Reproduce your own work - do work manually then recreate using agents as exercise, 2) End-of-day agents - block out last 30 minutes of every day to kick off agents, 3) Outsource the Slam Dunks - have agents handle tasks they can do while you work on something more interesting.
author: Simon Willison (curating Mitchell Hashimoto)

title: This is the most misunderstood graph in AI
description: Analysis of AI capability development trends and how the community interprets progress in artificial intelligence systems.
author: MIT Technology Review

title: Replit CEO Says AI Could End Soul-Crushing Corporate Work
description: Amjad Masad predicts that AI will eliminate tedious corporate work by 2026. He believes AI agents can remove workplace drudgery, allowing employees to build and own their ideas within large companies. Masad is targeting $1 billion in revenue by end of 2026.
author: Amjad Masad

title: SWE-Refactor: Repository-Level Benchmark for Real-World LLM Refactoring
description: Introduces a repository-level benchmark for evaluating LLM refactoring capabilities on real-world codebases, addressing the need for more comprehensive evaluation beyond single-file tasks.
author: ArXiv Researchers

title: Voxtral Transcribe 2: Transcribes at the speed of sound
description: Mistral released Voxtral Transcribe 2 - family of two new models for transcribing audio to text. Voxtral Realtime (Voxtral-Mini-4B-Realtime-2602) is open weights (Apache-2.0) available as 8.87GB download from Hugging Face. Closed weight model costs $0.003/minute ($0.18/hour).
author: Simon Willison

title: Distributing Go binaries through PyPI using go-to-wheel
description: Simon explores Go for building small, fast and self-contained binary applications. He enjoys that there's generally one obvious way to do things and the resulting code is boring and readable—and something that LLMs are very competent at writing. Publishing Go binaries to PyPI means any Go binary can be just a uvx package-name call away.
author: Simon Willison

title: A Challenging Benchmark for AI-Generated Code Detection
description: Addresses concerns about authorship and detection of LLM-generated functional source code.
author: ArXiv Researchers

title: Teaching NLP with LLM-Assisted 'Vibe Coding'
description: Pedagogical approach leveraging LLMs as coding assistants in NLP education.
author: ArXiv Researchers

title: A Task-Level Evaluation of AI Agents in Open-Source Projects
description: Comparative study of five autonomous coding agents using AIDev-pop dataset, evaluating performance on real open-source project tasks.
author: ArXiv Researchers
